<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-46"><a href="#External_links"><span class="tocnumber">17</span> <span class="toctext">External links</span></a></li>
</ul>
</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Background">Background</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>The view that human activities are likely responsible for most of the observed increase in global mean temperature ("global warming") since the mid-20th century is an accurate reflection of current scientific thinking.<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">[28]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-2008_us_nrc_Understanding_and_Responding_to_Climate_Change_29-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2008_us_nrc_Understanding_and_Responding_to_Climate_Change-29">[29]</a></sup> Human-induced warming of the climate is expected to continue throughout the 21st century and beyond.<sup id="cite_ref-2008_us_nrc_Understanding_and_Responding_to_Climate_Change_29-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2008_us_nrc_Understanding_and_Responding_to_Climate_Change-29">[29]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Intergovernmental_Panel_on_Climate_Change" title="Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change">Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change</a> (IPCC, 2007) have produced a range of projections of what the future increase in global mean temperature might be.<sup id="cite_ref-2007_ipcc_global_warming_projections_30-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2007_ipcc_global_warming_projections-30">[30]</a></sup>  The IPCC's projections are <a href="/w/index.php?title=Economics_of_climate_change_mitigation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Economics of climate change mitigation (page does not exist)">"baseline" projections</a>, meaning that they assume no future efforts are made to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. The IPCC projections cover the time period from the beginning of the 21st century to the end of the 21st century.<sup id="cite_ref-2007_ipcc_global_warming_projections_30-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2007_ipcc_global_warming_projections-30">[30]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">[31]</a></sup>  The "likely" range (as assessed to have a greater than 66% probability of being correct, based on the IPCC's expert judgement) is a projected increased in global mean temperature over the 21st century of between 1.1 and 6.4 °C.<sup id="cite_ref-2007_ipcc_global_warming_projections_30-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2007_ipcc_global_warming_projections-30">[30]</a></sup>
</p><p>The range in temperature projections partly reflects different projections of future greenhouse gas emissions.<sup id="cite_ref-2009_karl_ipcc_global_warming_projections_32-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2009_karl_ipcc_global_warming_projections-32">[32]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a>  Different projections contain different assumptions of future social and economic development (e.g., <a href="/wiki/Economic_growth" title="Economic growth">economic growth</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Population_projection&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Population projection (page does not exist)">population level</a>, <a href="/wiki/Energy_policy" title="Energy policy">energy policies</a>), which in turn affects projections of future greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions.<sup id="cite_ref-2009_karl_ipcc_global_warming_projections_32-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2009_karl_ipcc_global_warming_projections-32">[32]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a> The range also reflects uncertainty in the response of the climate system to past and future GHG emissions (measured by the <a href="/wiki/Climate_sensitivity" title="Climate sensitivity">climate sensitivity</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-2009_karl_ipcc_global_warming_projections_32-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2009_karl_ipcc_global_warming_projections-32">[32]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Chronology">Chronology</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p><b>1992</b> The UN Conference on the Environment and Development is held in Rio de Janeiro. It results in the Framework Convention on Climate Change <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.unfccc.int/">("FCCC" or "UNFCCC")</a> among other agreements.
</p><p><b>1995</b> Parties to the UNFCCC meet in Berlin (the 1st Conference of Parties (COP) to the UNFCCC) to outline specific targets on emissions.
</p><p><b>1997</b> In December the parties conclude the Kyoto Protocol in Kyoto, Japan, in which they agree to the broad outlines of emissions targets.
</p><p><b>2002</b> Russia and Canada ratify the Kyoto Protocol to the UNFCCC bringing the treaty into effect on 16 February 2005.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Article_2_of_the_UNFCCC">Article 2 of the UNFCCC</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>Most countries are Parties to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC).<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">[33]</a></sup>  Article 2 of the Convention states its ultimate objective, which is to stabilize the concentration of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere "at a level that would prevent dangerous anthropogenic (i.e., human) interference with the climate system."<sup id="cite_ref-2001d_ipcc_article_2_of_UNFCCC_34-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2001d_ipcc_article_2_of_UNFCCC-34">[34]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Natural_sciences" title="Natural sciences" class="mw-redirect">natural</a>, technical, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Social_sciences&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Social sciences (page does not exist)">social sciences</a> can provide information on decisions relating to this objective, e.g., the possible magnitude and rate of future climate changes.<sup id="cite_ref-2001d_ipcc_article_2_of_UNFCCC_34-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2001d_ipcc_article_2_of_UNFCCC-34">[34]</a></sup> However, the IPCC has also concluded that the decision of what constitutes "dangerous" interference requires value judgements, which will vary between different regions of the world.<sup id="cite_ref-2001d_ipcc_article_2_of_UNFCCC_34-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2001d_ipcc_article_2_of_UNFCCC-34">[34]</a></sup> Factors that might affect this decision include the local consequences of climate change impacts, the ability of a particular region to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Adaptation_to_global_warming&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Adaptation to global warming (page does not exist)">adapt to climate change</a> (adaptive capacity), and the ability of a region to <a href="/wiki/Climate_change_mitigation" title="Climate change mitigation">reduce its GHG emissions</a> (mitigative capacity).<sup id="cite_ref-2001d_ipcc_article_2_of_UNFCCC_34-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2001d_ipcc_article_2_of_UNFCCC-34">[34]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Objectives">Objectives</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Multiple_image&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Multiple image (page does not exist)">Template:Multiple image</a>
</p><p>The main aim of the Kyoto Protocol is to contain emissions of the main anthropogenic (i.e., human-emitted) greenhouse gases (GHGs) in ways that reflect underlying national differences in GHG emissions, wealth, and capacity to make the reductions.<sup id="cite_ref-2004_grubb_kyoto_35-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2004_grubb_kyoto-35">[35]</a></sup>  The treaty follows the main principles agreed in the original 1992 UN Framework Convention.<sup id="cite_ref-2004_grubb_kyoto_35-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2004_grubb_kyoto-35">[35]</a></sup>  According to the treaty, in 2012, Annex I Parties who have ratified the treaty must have fulfilled their obligations of greenhouse gas emissions limitations established for the Kyoto Protocol's first commitment period (2008–2012). These emissions limitation commitments are listed in Annex B of the Protocol.
</p><p>The Kyoto Protocol's first round commitments are the first detailed step taken within the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change (Gupta <i>et al.</i>, 2007).<sup id="cite_ref-gupta_36-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gupta-36">[36]</a></sup> The Protocol establishes a structure of rolling emission reduction commitment periods. It set a timetable starting in 2006 for negotiations to establish emission reduction commitments for a second commitment period (see <a href="/wiki/Kyoto_Protocol#Successor" title="Kyoto Protocol">Kyoto Protocol#Successor</a> for details).<sup id="cite_ref-grubb_commitments_37-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-grubb_commitments-37">[37]</a></sup> The first period emission reduction commitments expired on 31 December 2012.
</p><p>The ultimate objective of the UNFCCC is the "stabilization of greenhouse gas concentrations in the atmosphere at a level that would stop dangerous anthropogenic interference with the climate system."<sup id="cite_ref-unfccc2005_3-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-unfccc2005-3">[3]</a></sup> Even if Annex I Parties succeed in meeting their first-round commitments, much greater emission reductions will be required in future to stabilize atmospheric GHG concentrations.<sup id="cite_ref-grubb_commitments_37-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-grubb_commitments-37">[37]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ipcc_kyoto_stabilization_38-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ipcc_kyoto_stabilization-38">[38]</a></sup>
</p><p>For each of the different anthropogenic GHGs, different levels of emissions reductions would be required to meet the objective of stabilizing atmospheric concentrations (see <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Framework_Convention_on_Climate_Change#Stabilization_of_greenhouse_gas_concentrations" title="United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change">United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change#Stabilization of greenhouse gas concentrations</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-2007_meehl_stabilizing_atmospheric_concentrations_of_GHGs_39-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2007_meehl_stabilizing_atmospheric_concentrations_of_GHGs-39">[39]</a></sup>  <a href="/wiki/Carbon_dioxide" title="Carbon dioxide">Carbon dioxide</a> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Chem&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Chem (page does not exist)">Template:Chem</a>) is the most important anthropogenic GHG.<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">[40]</a></sup>  Stabilizing the concentration of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Chem&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Chem (page does not exist)">Template:Chem</a> in the atmosphere would ultimately require the effective elimination of anthropogenic <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Chem&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Chem (page does not exist)">Template:Chem</a> emissions.<sup id="cite_ref-2007_meehl_stabilizing_atmospheric_concentrations_of_GHGs_39-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2007_meehl_stabilizing_atmospheric_concentrations_of_GHGs-39">[39]</a></sup>
</p><p>Some of the principal concepts of the Kyoto Protocol are:
</p>
<ul>
<li>Binding commitments for the Annex I Parties. The main feature of the Protocol<sup id="cite_ref-2011_unfccc_kyoto_protocol_overview_41-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2011_unfccc_kyoto_protocol_overview-41">[41]</a></sup>  is that it established legally binding commitments to reduce emissions of greenhouse gases for Annex I Parties.  The commitments were based on the Berlin Mandate, which was a part of UNFCCC negotiations leading up to the Protocol.<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">[42]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-liverman_43-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-liverman-43">[43]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a>
</li>
<li>Implementation. In order to meet the objectives of the Protocol, Annex I Parties are required to prepare policies and measures for the reduction of greenhouse gases in their respective countries. In addition, they are required to increase the absorption of these gases and utilize all mechanisms available, such as joint implementation, the clean development mechanism and emissions trading, in order to be rewarded with credits that would allow more greenhouse gas emissions at home.
</li>
<li>Minimizing Impacts on Developing Countries by establishing an adaptation fund for climate change.
</li>
<li>Accounting, Reporting and Review in order to ensure the integrity of the Protocol.
</li>
<li>Compliance. Establishing a Compliance Committee to enforce compliance with the commitments under the Protocol.
</li>
</ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="First_commitment_period:_2008.E2.80.9312">First commitment period: 2008–12</span></h2>
<p>Under the Kyoto Protocol, 37 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Industrialized_countries&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Industrialized countries (page does not exist)">industrialized countries</a> and the <a href="/wiki/European_Community" title="European Community" class="mw-redirect">European Community</a> (the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a>-15, made up of 15 states at the time of the Kyoto negotiations) commit themselves to binding targets for GHG emissions.<sup id="cite_ref-2011_unfccc_kyoto_protocol_overview_41-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2011_unfccc_kyoto_protocol_overview-41">[41]</a></sup>  The targets apply to the four greenhouse gases <a href="/wiki/Carbon_dioxide" title="Carbon dioxide">carbon dioxide</a> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:CO2&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:CO2 (page does not exist)">Template:CO2</a>), <a href="/w/index.php?title=Methane&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Methane (page does not exist)">methane</a> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Chem&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Chem (page does not exist)">Template:Chem</a>), <a href="/wiki/Nitrous_oxide" title="Nitrous oxide">nitrous oxide</a> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Chem&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Chem (page does not exist)">Template:Chem</a>), <a href="/wiki/Sulphur_hexafluoride" title="Sulphur hexafluoride" class="mw-redirect">sulphur hexafluoride</a> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Chem&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Chem (page does not exist)">Template:Chem</a>), and two groups of gases, <a href="/wiki/Hydrofluorocarbon" title="Hydrofluorocarbon" class="mw-redirect">hydrofluorocarbons</a> (HFCs) and <a href="/wiki/Perfluorocarbon" title="Perfluorocarbon" class="mw-redirect">perfluorocarbons</a> (PFCs).<sup id="cite_ref-grubb_kyoto_gases_44-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-grubb_kyoto_gases-44">[44]</a></sup> The six GHG are translated into <a href="/w/index.php?title=Co2e&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Co2e (page does not exist)">CO<sub>2</sub> equivalents</a> in determining reductions in emissions.<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">[45]</a></sup> These reduction targets are in addition to the industrial gases, chlorofluorocarbons, or CFCs, which are dealt with under the 1987 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Montreal_Protocol_on_Substances_that_Deplete_the_Ozone_Layer&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Montreal Protocol on Substances that Deplete the Ozone Layer (page does not exist)">Montreal Protocol on Substances that Deplete the Ozone Layer</a>.
</p><p>Under the Protocol, only the Annex I Parties have committed themselves to national or joint reduction targets (formally called "quantified emission limitation and reduction objectives" (QELRO) – Article 4.1).<sup id="cite_ref-unfccc1997_46-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-unfccc1997-46">[46]</a></sup>  Parties to the Kyoto Protocol not listed in Annex I of the Convention (the non-Annex I Parties) are mostly low-income developing countries,<sup id="cite_ref-2005_unfccc_non-annex_i_summary_47-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2005_unfccc_non-annex_i_summary-47">[47]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a>  and may participate in the Kyoto Protocol through the Clean Development Mechanism (explained below).<sup id="cite_ref-grubb_commitments_37-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-grubb_commitments-37">[37]</a></sup>
</p><p>The emissions limitations of Annex I Parties varies between different Parties.<sup id="cite_ref-2011_unfccc_kyoto_protocol_targets_48-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2011_unfccc_kyoto_protocol_targets-48">[48]</a></sup>  Some Parties have emissions limitations reduce below the base year level, some have limitations at the base year level (i.e., no permitted increase above the base year level), while others have limitations above the base year level.
</p><p>Emission limits do not include emissions by international aviation and shipping.<sup id="cite_ref-shippingandaviation_49-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-shippingandaviation-49">[49]</a></sup> Although Belarus and Turkey are listed in the Convention's Annex I, they do not have emissions targets as they were not Annex I Parties when the Protocol was adopted.<sup id="cite_ref-2011_unfccc_kyoto_protocol_targets_48-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2011_unfccc_kyoto_protocol_targets-48">[48]</a></sup>  Kazakhstan does not have a target, but has declared that it wishes to become an Annex I Party to the Convention.<sup id="cite_ref-2011_unfccc_kyoto_protocol_targets_48-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2011_unfccc_kyoto_protocol_targets-48">[48]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Hidden_begin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Hidden begin (page does not exist)">Template:Hidden begin</a>
</p>
<table>

<tr>
<td style="width:25%; vertical-align:top;">
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Australia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Australia (page does not exist)">Australia</a> – 108% (2.1% of 1990 emissions) <br />
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Austria&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Austria (page does not exist)">Austria</a> –  87% <br />
<a href="/wiki/Belarus" title="Belarus">Belarus</a> – 95% (subject to acceptance by other parties)<br />
<a href="/wiki/Belgium" title="Belgium">Belgium</a> – 92.5% <br />
<a href="/wiki/Bulgaria" title="Bulgaria">Bulgaria</a> – 92% (0.6%) <br />
Canada – 94% (3.33%) <br />
<a href="/wiki/Croatia" title="Croatia">Croatia</a> – 95% () <br />
<a href="/wiki/Czech_Republic" title="Czech Republic">Czech Republic</a> – 92% (1.24%) <br />
<a href="/wiki/Denmark" title="Denmark">Denmark</a> – 79% <br />
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Estonia (page does not exist)">Estonia</a> – 92% (0.28%) <br />
</p>
</td>
<td style="width:25%; vertical-align:top;">
<p><a href="/wiki/Finland" title="Finland">Finland</a> – 100% <br />
<a href="/w/index.php?title=France&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="France (page does not exist)">France</a> – 100% <br />
<a href="/wiki/Germany" title="Germany">Germany</a> – 79% <br />
<a href="/wiki/Greece" title="Greece">Greece</a> – 125% <br />
<a href="/wiki/Hungary" title="Hungary">Hungary</a> – 94% (0.52%) <br />
<a href="/wiki/Iceland" title="Iceland">Iceland</a> – 110% (0.02%) <br />
<a href="/wiki/Ireland" title="Ireland">Ireland</a> – 113% <br />
<a href="/wiki/Italy" title="Italy">Italy</a> – 93.5% <br />
<a href="/wiki/Japan" title="Japan">Japan</a> – 94% (8.55%) <br />
<a href="/wiki/Latvia" title="Latvia">Latvia</a> – 92% (0.17%) <br />
</p>
</td>
<td style="width:25%; vertical-align:top;">
<p><a href="/wiki/Liechtenstein" title="Liechtenstein">Liechtenstein</a> – 92% (0.0015%) <br />
<a href="/wiki/Lithuania" title="Lithuania">Lithuania</a> – 92% () <br />
<a href="/wiki/Luxembourg" title="Luxembourg">Luxembourg</a> – 72% <br />
<a href="/wiki/Netherlands" title="Netherlands">Netherlands</a> – 94% <br />
<a href="/w/index.php?title=New_Zealand&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="New Zealand (page does not exist)">New Zealand</a> – 100% (0.19%) <br />
<a href="/wiki/Norway" title="Norway">Norway</a> – 101% (0.26%) <br />
<a href="/wiki/Poland" title="Poland">Poland</a> – 94% (3.02%) <br />
<a href="/wiki/Portugal" title="Portugal">Portugal</a> – 92% <br />
<a href="/wiki/Romania" title="Romania">Romania</a> – 92% (1.24%) <br />
</p>
</td>
<td style="width:25%; vertical-align:top;">
<p><a href="/wiki/Russian_Federation" title="Russian Federation" class="mw-redirect">Russian Federation</a> – 100% (17.4%) <br />
<a href="/wiki/Slovakia" title="Slovakia">Slovakia</a> – 92% (0.42%) <br />
<a href="/wiki/Slovenia" title="Slovenia">Slovenia</a> – 92% () <br />
Spain – 115% <br />
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Sweden&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sweden (page does not exist)">Sweden</a> – 104% <br />
<a href="/wiki/Switzerland" title="Switzerland">Switzerland</a> – 92% (0.32%) <br />
<a href="/wiki/Ukraine" title="Ukraine">Ukraine</a> – 100% () <br />
<a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom" title="United Kingdom">United Kingdom</a> – 87.5% <br />
<a href="/wiki/United_States_of_America" title="United States of America" class="mw-redirect">United States of America</a> – 93% (36.1%) (non-party)
</p>
</td></tr></table>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Hidden_end&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Hidden end (page does not exist)">Template:Hidden end</a>
</p><p>For most Parties, 1990 is the base year for the national GHG inventory and the calculation of the assigned amount.<sup id="cite_ref-2008_unfccc_kyoto_protocol_reference_manual_50-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2008_unfccc_kyoto_protocol_reference_manual-50">[50]</a></sup>  However, five Parties have an alternative base year:<sup id="cite_ref-2008_unfccc_kyoto_protocol_reference_manual_50-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2008_unfccc_kyoto_protocol_reference_manual-50">[50]</a></sup>
</p>
<ul>
<li> Bulgaria: 1988;
</li>
<li> Hungary: the average of the years 1985–87;
</li>
<li> Poland: 1988;
</li>
<li> Romania: 1989;
</li>
<li> Slovenia: 1986.
</li>
</ul>
<p>Annex I Parties can use a range of sophisticated "flexibility" mechanisms (see below) to meet their targets. Annex I Parties can achieve their targets by allocating reduced annual allowances to major operators within their borders, or by allowing these operators to exceed their allocations by offsetting any excess through a mechanism that is agreed by all the parties to the UNFCCC, such as by buying <a href="/wiki/Emissions_trading" title="Emissions trading">emission allowances</a> from other operators which have excess emissions credits.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Flexibility_mechanisms">Flexibility mechanisms</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>The Protocol defines three "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Flexibility_mechanisms&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Flexibility mechanisms (page does not exist)">flexibility mechanisms</a>" that can be used by Annex I Parties in meeting their emission limitation commitments.<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51">[51]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a>  The flexibility mechanisms are International Emissions Trading (IET), the <a href="/wiki/Clean_Development_Mechanism" title="Clean Development Mechanism">Clean Development Mechanism</a> (CDM), and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Joint_Implementation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Joint Implementation (page does not exist)">Joint Implementation</a> (JI). IET allows Annex I Parties to "trade" their emissions (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Assigned_amount_units&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Assigned amount units (page does not exist)">Assigned Amount Units</a>, AAUs, or "allowances" for short).<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">[52]</a></sup>
</p><p>The economic basis for providing this flexibility is that the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Margin_(economics)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Margin (economics) (page does not exist)">marginal</a> cost of reducing (or abating) emissions differs among countries.<sup id="cite_ref-toth_2001_flexibility_mechanisms_13-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-toth_2001_flexibility_mechanisms-13">[13]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a><sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">[53]</a></sup> "Marginal cost" is the cost of abating the last tonne of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Chem&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Chem (page does not exist)">Template:Chem</a>-eq for an Annex I/non-Annex I Party. At the time of the original Kyoto targets, studies suggested that  the flexibility mechanisms could reduce the overall (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Aggregate_data&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Aggregate data (page does not exist)">aggregate</a>) cost of meeting the targets.<sup id="cite_ref-hourcade_2001_economic_costs_of_flexibility_mechanisms_54-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hourcade_2001_economic_costs_of_flexibility_mechanisms-54">[54]</a></sup>  Studies also showed that national losses in Annex I <a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">gross domestic product</a> (GDP) could be reduced by use of the flexibility mechanisms.<sup id="cite_ref-hourcade_2001_economic_costs_of_flexibility_mechanisms_54-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hourcade_2001_economic_costs_of_flexibility_mechanisms-54">[54]</a></sup>
</p><p>The CDM and JI are called "project-based mechanisms," in that they generate emission reductions from projects. The difference between IET and the project-based mechanisms is that IET is based on the setting of a quantitative restriction of emissions, while the CDM and JI are based on the idea of "production" of emission reductions.<sup id="cite_ref-toth_2001_flexibility_mechanisms_13-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-toth_2001_flexibility_mechanisms-13">[13]</a></sup>  The CDM is designed to encourage production of emission reductions in non-Annex I Parties, while JI encourages production of emission reductions in Annex I Parties.
</p><p>The production of emission reductions generated by the CDM and JI can be used by Annex I Parties in meeting their emission limitation commitments.<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55">[55]</a></sup> The emission reductions produced by the CDM and JI are both measured against a hypothetical <a href="/w/index.php?title=Economics_of_climate_change_mitigation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Economics of climate change mitigation (page does not exist)">baseline</a> of emissions that would have occurred in the absence of a particular emission reduction project. The emission reductions produced by the CDM are called <a href="/w/index.php?title=Certified_Emission_Reduction&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Certified Emission Reduction (page does not exist)">Certified Emission Reductions</a> (CERs); reductions produced by JI are called <a href="/w/index.php?title=Emission_Reduction_Unit&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Emission Reduction Unit (page does not exist)">Emission Reduction Units</a> (ERUs). The reductions are called "<a href="/wiki/Carbon_credit" title="Carbon credit">credits</a>" because they are emission reductions credited against a hypothetical baseline of emissions.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}}
</p><p>Each Annex I country is required to submit an annual report of inventories of all anthropogenic greenhouse gas emissions from sources and removals from sinks under UNFCCC and the Kyoto Protocol. These countries nominate a person (called a "designated national authority") to create and manage its <a href="/w/index.php?title=Greenhouse_gas_inventory&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Greenhouse gas inventory (page does not exist)">greenhouse gas inventory</a>. Virtually all of the non-Annex I countries have also established a designated national authority to manage their Kyoto obligations, specifically the "CDM process". This determines which GHG projects they wish to propose for accreditation by the CDM Executive Board.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="International_Emissions_Trading">International Emissions Trading</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>A number of emissions trading schemes (ETS) have been, or are planned to be, implemented.<sup id="cite_ref-hood_56-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hood-56">[56]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Asia">Asia</span></h4>
<ul>
<li><i>Japan:</i> emissions trading in Tokyo started in 2010. This scheme is run by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tokyo_Metropolitan_Government&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tokyo Metropolitan Government (page does not exist)">Tokyo Metropolitan Government</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-hood_56-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hood-56">[56]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a>
</li>
</ul>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Europe">Europe</span></h4>
<ul>
<li><i><a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a>:</i> the <a href="/wiki/European_Union_Emission_Trading_Scheme" title="European Union Emission Trading Scheme">European Union Emissions Trading System</a> (EU ETS), which started in 2005. This is run by the <a href="/wiki/European_Commission" title="European Commission">European Commission</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-hood_56-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hood-56">[56]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a>
</li>
<li><i><a href="/wiki/Norway" title="Norway">Norway</a></i>: domestic emissions trading in Norway started in 2005.<sup id="cite_ref-hood_56-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hood-56">[56]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a> This was run by the Norwegian Government, which is now a participant in the EU ETS.
</li>
<li><i><a href="/wiki/Switzerland" title="Switzerland">Switzerland</a></i>: the Swiss ETS, which runs from 2008 to 2012, to coincide with the Kyoto Protocol's first commitment period.<sup id="cite_ref-hood_56-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hood-56">[56]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a>
</li>
<li><i>United Kingdom:</i>
<ul>
<li>the <a href="/w/index.php?title=UK_Emissions_Trading_Scheme&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="UK Emissions Trading Scheme (page does not exist)">UK Emissions Trading Scheme</a>, which ran from 2002–06. This was a scheme run by the UK Government, which is now a participant in the EU ETS.<sup id="cite_ref-hood_56-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hood-56">[56]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a>
</li>
<li>the UK <a href="/w/index.php?title=CRC_Energy_Efficiency_Scheme&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="CRC Energy Efficiency Scheme (page does not exist)">CRC Energy Efficiency Scheme</a>, which started in 2010, and is run by the UK Government.<sup id="cite_ref-hood_56-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hood-56">[56]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a>
</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="North_America">North America</span></h4>
<ul>
<li><i>Canada:</i> emissions trading in <a href="/wiki/Alberta" title="Alberta">Alberta</a>, Canada, which started in 2007. This is run by the <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Alberta" title="Government of Alberta" class="mw-redirect">Government of Alberta</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-hood_56-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hood-56">[56]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a>
</li>
<li><i>United States:</i>
<ul>
<li>the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Regional_Greenhouse_Gas_Initiative&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative (page does not exist)">Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative</a> (RGGI), which started in 2009. This scheme caps emissions from power generation in ten north-eastern U.S. states (Connecticut, Delaware, Maine, Maryland, Massachusetts, New Hampshire, New Jersey, New York, Rhode Island and Vermont).<sup id="cite_ref-hood_56-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hood-56">[56]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a>
</li>
<li>emissions trading in California, which is planned to start in 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-hood_56-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hood-56">[56]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a>
</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Western_Climate_Initiative&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Western Climate Initiative (page does not exist)">Western Climate Initiative</a> (WCI), which is planned to start in 2012. This is a collective ETS agreed between 11 U.S. states and <a href="/wiki/Canadian_province" title="Canadian province" class="mw-redirect">Canadian provinces</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-hood_56-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hood-56">[56]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a>
</li>
</ul>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Oceania">Oceania</span></h4>
<ul>
<li><i>Australia:</i> the <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_South_Wales_Greenhouse_Gas_Abatement_Scheme&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="New South Wales Greenhouse Gas Abatement Scheme (page does not exist)">New South Wales Greenhouse Gas Reduction Scheme</a> (NSW), which started in 2003. This scheme is run by the Australian <a href="/w/index.php?title=State_of_New_South_Wales&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="State of New South Wales (page does not exist)">State of New South Wales</a>, and has now joined the Alfa Climate Stabilization (ACS).<sup id="cite_ref-hood_56-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hood-56">[56]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a>
</li>
<li><i>New Zealand</i>: the <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_Zealand_Emissions_Trading_Scheme&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="New Zealand Emissions Trading Scheme (page does not exist)">New Zealand Emissions Trading Scheme</a>, which started in 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-hood_56-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hood-56">[56]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a>
</li>
</ul>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Intergovernmental_Emissions_Trading">Intergovernmental Emissions Trading</span></h4>
<p>The design of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=European_Union_Emissions_Trading_Scheme&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="European Union Emissions Trading Scheme (page does not exist)">European Union Emissions Trading Scheme</a> (EU ETS) implicitly allows for trade of national Kyoto obligations to occur between participating countries (Carbon Trust, 2009, p.&#160;24).<sup id="cite_ref-2009_carbon_trust_carbon_market_57-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2009_carbon_trust_carbon_market-57">[57]</a></sup> Carbon Trust (2009, pp.&#160;24–25) found that other than the trading that occurs as part of the EU ETS, no intergovernmental emissions trading had taken place.<sup id="cite_ref-2009_carbon_trust_carbon_market_57-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2009_carbon_trust_carbon_market-57">[57]</a></sup>
</p><p>One of the environmental problems with IET is the large surplus of allowances that are available. Russia, Ukraine, and the new EU-12 member states (the Kyoto Parties Annex I Economies-in-Transition, abbreviated "EIT": Belarus, Bulgaria, Croatia, Czech Republic, Estonia, Hungary, Latvia, Lithuania, Poland, Romania, Russia, Slovakia, Slovenia, and Ukraine)<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">[58]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a> have a surplus of allowances, while many <a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD" class="mw-redirect">OECD</a> countries have a deficit.<sup id="cite_ref-2009_carbon_trust_carbon_market_57-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2009_carbon_trust_carbon_market-57">[57]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a>  Some of the EITs with a surplus regard it as potential compensation for the trauma of their economic restructuring.<sup id="cite_ref-2009_carbon_trust_carbon_market_57-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2009_carbon_trust_carbon_market-57">[57]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a> When the Kyoto treaty was negotiated, it was recognized that emissions targets for the EITs might lead to them having an excess number of allowances.<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59">[59]</a></sup>  This excess of allowances were viewed by the EITs as "headroom" to grow their economies.<sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60">[60]</a></sup>  The surplus has, however, also been referred to by some as "hot air," a term which Russia (a country with an estimated surplus of 3.1 billion tonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent allowances) views as "quite offensive."<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61">[61]</a></sup>
</p><p>OECD countries with a deficit could meet their Kyoto commitments by buying allowances from transition countries with a surplus. Unless other commitments were made to reduce the total surplus in allowances, such trade would not actually result in emissions being reduced<sup id="cite_ref-2009_carbon_trust_carbon_market_57-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2009_carbon_trust_carbon_market-57">[57]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a> (see also the section below on the <a href="/wiki/Kyoto_Protocol#Green_Investment_Scheme" title="Kyoto Protocol">Green Investment Scheme</a>).
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Green_Investment_Scheme">Green Investment Scheme</span></h4>
<p>A Green Investment Scheme (GIS) refers to a plan for achieving environmental benefits from trading surplus allowances (AAUs) under the Kyoto Protocol.<sup id="cite_ref-Definition_of_Green_Investment_Scheme_.28GIS.29_62-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Definition_of_Green_Investment_Scheme_.28GIS.29-62">[62]</a></sup> The Green Investment Scheme (GIS), a mechanism in the framework of International Emissions Trading (IET), is designed to achieve greater flexibility in reaching the targets of the Kyoto Protocol while preserving environmental integrity of IET. However, using the GIS is not required under the Kyoto Protocol, and there is no official definition of the term.<sup id="cite_ref-Definition_of_Green_Investment_Scheme_.28GIS.29_62-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Definition_of_Green_Investment_Scheme_.28GIS.29-62">[62]</a></sup>
</p><p>Under the GIS a Party to the Protocol expecting that the development of its economy will not exhaust its Kyoto quota, can sell the excess of its Kyoto quota units (AAUs) to another Party. The proceeds from the AAU sales should be "greened", i.e. channeled to the development and implementation of the projects either acquiring the greenhouse gases emission reductions (hard greening) or building up the necessary framework for this process (soft greening).<sup id="cite_ref-2009_carbon_trust_carbon_market_57-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2009_carbon_trust_carbon_market-57">[57]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Trade_in_AAUs">Trade in AAUs</span></h4>
<p>Latvia was one of the front-runners of GISs. World Bank (2011)<sup id="cite_ref-world_bank_2011_trade_in_aaus_63-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-world_bank_2011_trade_in_aaus-63">[63]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a>  reported that Latvia has stopped offering AAU sales because of low AAU prices. In 2010, Estonia was the preferred source for AAU buyers, followed by the Czech Republic and Poland.<sup id="cite_ref-world_bank_2011_trade_in_aaus_63-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-world_bank_2011_trade_in_aaus-63">[63]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a>
</p><p>Japan's national policy to meet their Kyoto target includes the purchase of AAUs sold under GISs.<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">[64]</a></sup>  In 2010, Japan and Japanese firms were the main buyers of AAUs.<sup id="cite_ref-world_bank_2011_trade_in_aaus_63-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-world_bank_2011_trade_in_aaus-63">[63]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a>  In terms of the international carbon market, trade in AAUs are a small proportion of overall market value.<sup id="cite_ref-world_bank_2011_trade_in_aaus_63-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-world_bank_2011_trade_in_aaus-63">[63]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a> In 2010, 97% of trade in the international carbon market was driven by the <a href="/wiki/European_Union_Emission_Trading_Scheme" title="European Union Emission Trading Scheme">European Union Emissions Trading System</a> (EU ETS).<sup id="cite_ref-world_bank_2011_trade_in_aaus_63-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-world_bank_2011_trade_in_aaus-63">[63]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a>  However, firms regulated under the EU ETS are unable to use AAUs in meeting their emissions caps.<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">[65]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Clean_Development_Mechanism">Clean Development Mechanism</span></h4>
<p>Between 2001, which was the first year <a href="/wiki/Clean_Development_Mechanism" title="Clean Development Mechanism">Clean Development Mechanism</a> (CDM) projects could be registered, and 2012, the end of the first Kyoto commitment period, the CDM is expected to produce some 1.5&#160;billion tons of carbon dioxide equivalent (CO<sub>2</sub>e) in emission reductions.<sup id="cite_ref-wdr_66-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wdr-66">[66]</a></sup> Most of these reductions are through <a href="/w/index.php?title=Renewable_energy_commercialisation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Renewable energy commercialisation (page does not exist)">renewable energy commercialisation</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Efficient_energy_use&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Efficient energy use (page does not exist)">energy efficiency</a>, and fuel switching (World Bank, 2010, p.&#160;262). By 2012, the largest potential for production of CERs are estimated in <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a> (52% of total CERs) and India (16%). CERs produced in Latin America and the Caribbean make up 15% of the potential total, with Brazil as the largest producer in the region (7%).
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Joint_Implementation">Joint Implementation</span></h4>
<p>The formal crediting period for <a href="/w/index.php?title=Joint_Implementation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Joint Implementation (page does not exist)">Joint Implementation</a> (JI) was aligned with the first commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol, and did not start until January 2008 (Carbon Trust, 2009, p.&#160;20).<sup id="cite_ref-2009_carbon_trust_carbon_market_57-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2009_carbon_trust_carbon_market-57">[57]</a></sup> In November 2008, only 22 JI projects had been officially approved and registered. The total projected emission savings from JI by 2012 are about one tenth that of the CDM. Russia accounts for about two-thirds of these savings, with the remainder divided up roughly equally between the Ukraine and the EU's New Member States. Emission savings include cuts in methane, HFC, and N<sub>2</sub>O emissions.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Stabilization_of_GHG_concentrations">Stabilization of GHG concentrations</span></h2>
<p>As noted <a href="/wiki/Kyoto_Protocol#Objectives" title="Kyoto Protocol">earlier on</a>, the first-round Kyoto emissions limitation commitments are not sufficient to stabilize the atmospheric concentration of GHGs. Stabilization of atmospheric GHG concentrations will require further emissions reductions after the end of the first-round Kyoto commitment period in 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-grubb_commitments_37-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-grubb_commitments-37">[37]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ipcc_kyoto_stabilization_38-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ipcc_kyoto_stabilization-38">[38]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Background_2">Background</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Multiple_image&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Multiple image (page does not exist)">Template:Multiple image</a>
</p><p>Analysts have developed <a href="/w/index.php?title=Climate_change_scenario&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Climate change scenario (page does not exist)">scenarios</a> of future changes in GHG emissions that lead to a stabilization in the atmospheric concentrations of GHGs.<sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67">[67]</a></sup>  Climate models suggest that lower stabilization levels are associated with lower magnitudes of future global warming, while higher stabilization levels are associated with higher magnitudes of future global warming (see figure opposite).<sup id="cite_ref-global_warming_and_stabilization_targets_68-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-global_warming_and_stabilization_targets-68">[68]</a></sup>
</p><p>To achieve stabilization, global GHG emissions must peak, then decline.<sup id="cite_ref-emissions_peak_and_decline_69-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-emissions_peak_and_decline-69">[69]</a></sup>  The lower the desired stabilization level, the sooner this peak and decline must occur (see figure opposite).<sup id="cite_ref-emissions_peak_and_decline_69-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-emissions_peak_and_decline-69">[69]</a></sup> For a given stabilization level, larger emissions reductions in the near term allow for less stringent emissions reductions later on.<sup id="cite_ref-near_term_emissions_reductions_70-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-near_term_emissions_reductions-70">[70]</a></sup> On the other hand, less stringent near term emissions reductions would, for a given stabilization level, require more stringent emissions reductions later on.<sup id="cite_ref-near_term_emissions_reductions_70-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-near_term_emissions_reductions-70">[70]</a></sup>
</p><p>The first period Kyoto emissions limitations can be viewed as a first-step towards achieving atmospheric stabilization of GHGs.<sup id="cite_ref-gupta_36-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gupta-36">[36]</a></sup> In this sense, the first period Kyoto commitments may affect what future atmospheric stabilization level can be achieved.<sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">[71]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Relation_to_temperature_targets">Relation to temperature targets</span></h3>
<p>At the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_United_Nations_Climate_Change_Conference&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2010 United Nations Climate Change Conference (page does not exist)">16th Conference of the Parties</a> held in 2010, Parties to the UNFCCC agreed that future global warming should be limited <a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_United_Nations_Climate_Change_Conference&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2010 United Nations Climate Change Conference (page does not exist)">below 2°C</a> relative to the pre-industrial temperature level.<sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72">[72]</a></sup>  One of the stabilization levels discussed in relation to this temperature target is to hold atmospheric concentrations of GHGs at 450 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Parts_per_million&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Parts per million (page does not exist)">parts per million</a> (ppm) <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Chem&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Chem (page does not exist)">Template:Chem</a>- eq.<sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73">[73]</a></sup>  Stabilization at 450&#160;ppm could be associated with a 26 to 78% risk of exceeding the 2°C target.<sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74">[74]</a></sup>
</p><p>Scenarios assessed by Gupta <i>et al.</i> (2007)<sup id="cite_ref-450ppm_scenarios_75-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-450ppm_scenarios-75">[75]</a></sup> suggest that Annex I emissions would need to be 25% to 40% below 1990 levels by 2020, and 80% to 95% below 1990 levels by 2050. The only Annex I Parties to have made voluntary pledges in line with this are Japan (25% below 1990 levels by 2020) and Norway (30-40% below 1990 levels by 2020).<sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76">[76]</a></sup>
</p><p>Gupta <i>et al.</i> (2007)<sup id="cite_ref-450ppm_scenarios_75-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-450ppm_scenarios-75">[75]</a></sup> also looked at what 450&#160;ppm scenarios projected for non-Annex I Parties. Projections indicated that by 2020, non-Annex I emissions in several regions (<a href="/wiki/Latin_America" title="Latin America">Latin America</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Middle_East" title="Middle East">Middle East</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=East_Asia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="East Asia (page does not exist)">East Asia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Planned_economy" title="Planned economy">centrally planned</a> <a href="/wiki/Asia" title="Asia">Asia</a>) would need to be substantially reduced below <a href="/w/index.php?title=Economics_of_climate_change_mitigation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Economics of climate change mitigation (page does not exist)">"business-as-usual"</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-450ppm_scenarios_75-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-450ppm_scenarios-75">[75]</a></sup> "Business-as-usual" are projected non-Annex I emissions in the absence of any new policies to control emissions. Projections indicated that by 2050, emissions in all non-Annex I regions would need to be substantially reduced below "business-as-usual".<sup id="cite_ref-450ppm_scenarios_75-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-450ppm_scenarios-75">[75]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Details_of_the_agreement">Details of the agreement</span></h2>
<p>The agreement is a protocol to the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Framework_Convention_on_Climate_Change" title="United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change">United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change</a> (UNFCCC) adopted at the <a href="/wiki/Earth_Summit" title="Earth Summit">Earth Summit</a> in <a href="/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro" title="Rio de Janeiro">Rio de Janeiro</a> in 1992, which did not set any legally binding limitations on emissions or enforcement mechanisms. Only Parties to the UNFCCC can become Parties to the Kyoto Protocol. The Kyoto Protocol was adopted at the third session of the Conference of Parties to the UNFCCC (COP 3) in 1997 in Kyoto, Japan.
</p><p>National emission targets specified in the Kyoto Protocol exclude international aviation and shipping. Kyoto Parties can use <a href="/wiki/Land_use" title="Land use">land use</a>, land use change, and <a href="/wiki/Forestry" title="Forestry">forestry</a> (LULUCF) in meeting their targets.<sup id="cite_ref-Dessai_2001_3_77-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dessai_2001_3-77">[77]</a></sup>  LULUCF activities are also called "sink" activities. Changes in sinks and land use can have an effect on the climate,<sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78">[78]</a></sup> and indeed the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change's Special Report on Land Use, Land-Use Change and Forestry estimates that since 1750 a third of global warming has been caused by land use change.<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79">[79]</a></sup> Particular criteria apply to the definition of forestry under the Kyoto Protocol.
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Forest_management&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Forest management (page does not exist)">Forest management</a>, <a href="/wiki/Farm" title="Farm">cropland</a> management, <a href="/wiki/Grazing" title="Grazing">grazing</a> land management, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Revegetation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Revegetation (page does not exist)">revegetation</a> are all eligible LULUCF activities under the Protocol.<sup id="cite_ref-forest_management_80-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-forest_management-80">[80]</a></sup>  Annex I Parties use of forest management in meeting their targets is capped.<sup id="cite_ref-forest_management_80-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-forest_management-80">[80]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Negotiations">Negotiations</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>Article 4.2 of the UNFCCC commits industrialized countries to "[take] the lead" in reducing emissions.<sup id="cite_ref-grubb_original_unfccc_target_81-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-grubb_original_unfccc_target-81">[81]</a></sup> The initial aim was for industrialized countries to stabilize their emissions at 1990 levels by the year 2000.<sup id="cite_ref-grubb_original_unfccc_target_81-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-grubb_original_unfccc_target-81">[81]</a></sup> The failure of key industrialized countries to move in this direction was a principal reason why Kyoto moved to binding commitments.<sup id="cite_ref-grubb_original_unfccc_target_81-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-grubb_original_unfccc_target-81">[81]</a></sup>
</p><p>At the first UNFCCC Conference of the Parties in Berlin, the <a href="/wiki/Group_of_77" title="Group of 77">G77</a> was able to push for a mandate (the "Berlin mandate") where it was recognized that:<sup id="cite_ref-liverman_berlin_mandate_82-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-liverman_berlin_mandate-82">[82]</a></sup>
</p>
<ul>
<li>developed nations had contributed most to the then-current concentrations of GHGs in the atmosphere (see <a href="/w/index.php?title=Greenhouse_gas&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Greenhouse gas (page does not exist)">Greenhouse gas#Cumulative and historical emissions</a>).
</li>
<li>developing country <a href="/w/index.php?title=Greenhouse_gas&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Greenhouse gas (page does not exist)">emissions per-capita</a> (i.e., average emissions per head of population)<sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83">[83]</a></sup> were still relatively low.
</li>
<li>and that the share of global emissions from developing countries would grow to meet their development needs.
</li>
</ul>
<p>During negotiations, the G-77 represented 133 developing countries. China was not a member of the group but an associate.<sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84">[84]</a></sup> It has since become a member.<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">[85]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Berlin mandate was recognized in the Kyoto Protocol in that developing countries were not subject to emission reduction commitments in the first Kyoto commitment period.<sup id="cite_ref-liverman_berlin_mandate_82-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-liverman_berlin_mandate-82">[82]</a></sup> However, the large potential for growth in developing country emissions made negotiations on this issue tense.<sup id="cite_ref-grubb_developing_country_emissions_86-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-grubb_developing_country_emissions-86">[86]</a></sup> In the final agreement, the Clean Development Mechanism was designed to limit emissions in developing countries, but in such a way that developing countries do not bear the costs for limiting emissions.<sup id="cite_ref-grubb_developing_country_emissions_86-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-grubb_developing_country_emissions-86">[86]</a></sup> The general assumption was that developing countries would face quantitative commitments in later commitment periods, and at the same time, developed countries would meet their first round commitments.<sup id="cite_ref-grubb_developing_country_emissions_86-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-grubb_developing_country_emissions-86">[86]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Emissions_cuts">Emissions cuts</span></h4>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Views_on_the_Kyoto_Protocol&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Views on the Kyoto Protocol (page does not exist)">Views on the Kyoto Protocol#Commentaries on negotiations</a> contains a list of the emissions cuts that were proposed by UNFCCC Parties during negotiations. The G77 and China were in favour of strong uniform emission cuts across the developed world.<sup id="cite_ref-liverman_negotiations_87-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-liverman_negotiations-87">[87]</a></sup> The U.S. originally proposed for the second round of negotiations on Kyoto commitments to follow the negotiations of the first.<sup id="cite_ref-grubb_second_round_negotiations_88-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-grubb_second_round_negotiations-88">[88]</a></sup> In the end, negotiations on the second period were set to open no later than 2005.<sup id="cite_ref-grubb_second_round_negotiations_88-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-grubb_second_round_negotiations-88">[88]</a></sup> Countries over-achieving in their first period commitments can "bank" their unused allowances for use in the subsequent period.<sup id="cite_ref-grubb_second_round_negotiations_88-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-grubb_second_round_negotiations-88">[88]</a></sup>
</p><p>The EU initially argued for only three GHGs to be included – <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:CO2&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:CO2 (page does not exist)">Template:CO2</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Chem&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Chem (page does not exist)">Template:Chem</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Chem&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Chem (page does not exist)">Template:Chem</a> – with other gases such as HFCs regulated separately.<sup id="cite_ref-liverman_negotiations_87-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-liverman_negotiations-87">[87]</a></sup> The EU also wanted to have a "bubble" commitment, whereby it could make a collective commitment that allowed some EU members to increase their emissions, while others cut theirs.<sup id="cite_ref-liverman_negotiations_87-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-liverman_negotiations-87">[87]</a></sup>
</p><p>The most vulnerable nations – the <a href="/wiki/Alliance_of_Small_Island_States" title="Alliance of Small Island States">Alliance of Small Island States</a> (AOSIS) – pushed for deep uniform cuts by developed nations, with the goal of having emissions reduced to the greatest possible extent.<sup id="cite_ref-liverman_negotiations_87-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-liverman_negotiations-87">[87]</a></sup> Countries that had supported differentiation of targets had different ideas as to how it should be calculated, and many different indicators were proposed.<sup id="cite_ref-grubb_differentiation_89-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-grubb_differentiation-89">[89]</a></sup> Two examples include differentiation of targets based on <a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">gross domestic product</a> (GDP), and differentiation based on <a href="/wiki/Energy_intensity" title="Energy intensity">energy intensity</a> (energy use per unit of economic output).<sup id="cite_ref-grubb_differentiation_89-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-grubb_differentiation-89">[89]</a></sup>
</p><p>The final targets negotiated in the Protocol are the result of last minute political compromises.<sup id="cite_ref-liverman_negotiations_87-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-liverman_negotiations-87">[87]</a></sup> The targets closely match those decided by Argentinian Raul Estrada, the <a href="/wiki/Diplomat" title="Diplomat">diplomat</a> who chaired the negotiations.<sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90">[90]</a></sup>  The numbers given to each Party by Chairman Estrada were based on targets already pledged by Parties, information received on latest negotiating positions, and the goal of achieving the strongest possible environmental outcome.<sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91">[91]</a></sup> The final targets are weaker than those proposed by some Parties, e.g., the <a href="/wiki/Alliance_of_Small_Island_States" title="Alliance of Small Island States">Alliance of Small Island States</a> and the G-77 and China, but stronger than the targets proposed by others, e.g., Canada and the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-92" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-92">[92]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Financial_commitments">Financial commitments</span></h3>
<p>The Protocol also reaffirms the principle that developed countries have to pay billions of dollars, and supply technology to other countries for climate-related studies and projects. The principle was originally agreed in <a href="/wiki/UNFCCC" title="UNFCCC" class="mw-redirect">UNFCCC</a>. One such project is <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Adaptation_Fund&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Adaptation Fund (page does not exist)">The Adaptation Fund</a>"<sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93">[93]</a></sup>", that has been established by the Parties to the Kyoto Protocol of the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change to finance concrete adaptation projects and programmes in developing countries that are Parties to the Kyoto Protocol.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Implementational_provisions">Implementational provisions</span></h3>
<p>The protocol left several issues open to be decided later by the sixth Conference of Parties <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_Nations_Climate_Change_conference&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United Nations Climate Change conference (page does not exist)">COP6</a> of the UNFCCC, which attempted to resolve these issues at its meeting in <a href="/wiki/The_Hague" title="The Hague">the Hague</a> in late 2000, but it was unable to reach an agreement due to disputes between the European Union (who favoured a tougher implementation) and the United States, Canada, Japan and Australia (who wanted the agreement to be less demanding and more flexible).
</p><p>In 2001, a continuation of the previous meeting (COP6bis) was held in <a href="/wiki/Bonn" title="Bonn">Bonn</a> where the required decisions were adopted. After some concessions, the supporters of the protocol (led by the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a>) managed to get the agreement of Japan and <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russia</a> by allowing more use of <a href="/wiki/CO2_sink" title="CO2 sink" class="mw-redirect">carbon dioxide sinks</a>.
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=United_Nations_Climate_Change_conference&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United Nations Climate Change conference (page does not exist)">COP7</a> was held from 29 October 2001 through 9 November 2001 in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Marrakech&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Marrakech (page does not exist)">Marrakech</a> to establish the final details of the protocol.
</p><p>The first Meeting of the Parties to the Kyoto Protocol (MOP1) was held in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Montreal&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Montreal (page does not exist)">Montreal</a> from 28 November to 9 December 2005, along with the 11th conference of the Parties to the UNFCCC (COP11). See <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_Nations_Climate_Change_Conference&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United Nations Climate Change Conference (page does not exist)">United Nations Climate Change Conference</a>.
</p><p>During COP13 in Bali 36 developed <a href="/w/index.php?title=Contact_Group&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Contact Group (page does not exist)">C.G.</a> countries (plus the EU as a party in the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a>) agreed to a 10% emissions increase for <a href="/wiki/Iceland" title="Iceland">Iceland</a>; but, since the EU's member states each have individual obligations,<sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94">[94]</a></sup> much larger increases (up to 27%) are allowed for some of the less developed EU countries (see below <a href="/wiki/Kyoto_Protocol#Increase_in_greenhouse_gas_emission_since_1990" title="Kyoto Protocol">Kyoto Protocol#Increase in greenhouse gas emission since 1990</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-95">[95]</a></sup> Reduction limitations expire in 2013.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Mechanism_of_compliance">Mechanism of compliance</span></h3>
<p>The protocol defines a mechanism of "compliance" as a "monitoring compliance with the commitments and penalties for non-compliance."<sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96">[96]</a></sup> According to Grubb (2003),<sup id="cite_ref-grubb_compliance_97-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-grubb_compliance-97">[97]</a></sup> the explicit consequences of non-compliance of the treaty are weak compared to domestic law.<sup id="cite_ref-grubb_compliance_97-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-grubb_compliance-97">[97]</a></sup> Yet, the compliance section of the treaty was highly contested in the Marrakesh Accords.<sup id="cite_ref-grubb_compliance_97-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-grubb_compliance-97">[97]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Enforcement">Enforcement</span></h3>
<p>If the enforcement branch determines that an Annex I country is not in compliance with its emissions limitation, then that country is required to make up the difference during the second commitment period plus an additional 30%.  In addition, that country will be suspended from making transfers under an emissions trading program.<sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98">[98]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Ratification_process">Ratification process</span></h2>
<p>The Protocol was adopted by <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Framework_Convention_on_Climate_Change" title="United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change">COP 3</a> of UNFCC on 11 December 1997 in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kyoto,_Japan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kyoto, Japan (page does not exist)">Kyoto, Japan</a>. It was opened on 16 March 1998 for signature during one year by parties to <a href="/wiki/UNFCCC" title="UNFCCC" class="mw-redirect">UNFCCC</a>, when it was signed Antigua and Barbuda, Argentina, the Maldives, Samoa, St. Lucia and Switzerland. At the end of the signature period, 82 countries and the <a href="/wiki/European_Community" title="European Community" class="mw-redirect">European Community</a> had signed. <a href="/wiki/Ratification" title="Ratification">Ratification</a> (which is required to become a party to the Protocol) started on 17 September with ratification of Fiji. Countries that did not sign acceded to the convention, which has the same legal effect.<sup id="cite_ref-parties_7-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-parties-7">[7]</a></sup>
</p><p>Article 25 of the Protocol specifies that the Protocol enters into force "on the ninetieth day after the date on which not less than 55 Parties to the Convention, incorporating Parties included in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Annex_I&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Annex I (page does not exist)">Annex I</a> which accounted in total for at least 55% of the total carbon dioxide emissions for 1990 of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Annex_I&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Annex I (page does not exist)">Annex I</a> countries, have deposited their instruments of ratification, acceptance, approval or accession."<sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99">[99]</a></sup>
</p><p>The EU and its Member States ratified the Protocol in May 2002.<sup id="cite_ref-100" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100">[100]</a></sup> Of the two conditions, the "55 parties" clause was reached on 23 May 2002 when <a href="/wiki/Iceland" title="Iceland">Iceland</a> ratified the Protocol.<sup id="cite_ref-parties_7-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-parties-7">[7]</a></sup> The ratification by <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russia</a> on 18 November 2004 satisfied the "55%" clause and brought the treaty into force, effective 16 February 2005, after the required lapse of 90 days.<sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101">[101]</a></sup>
</p><p>On 3 December 2007, Australia ratified the protocol during the first day of the COP13 in Bali.
</p><p>As of May 2013, <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_Kyoto_Protocol_signatories&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of Kyoto Protocol signatories (page does not exist)">191 countries</a> and one regional economic organization (the <a href="/wiki/European_Economic_Community" title="European Economic Community">EC</a>) have ratified the agreement, representing over 61.6% of the 1990 emissions from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Annex_I&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Annex I (page does not exist)">Annex I</a> countries.<sup id="cite_ref-Kyoto-PDF-unfccc_102-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kyoto-PDF-unfccc-102">[102]</a></sup> One of the 191 ratifying states—Canada—has denounced the protocol.
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Hidden_begin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Hidden begin (page does not exist)">Template:Hidden begin</a>
</p>

United States (non-party to Kyoto) <br />
<a href="/wiki/Uruguay" title="Uruguay">Uruguay</a> <br />
