<a href="/wiki/Yemen" title="Yemen">Yemen</a> <br />
<a href="/wiki/Zambia" title="Zambia">Zambia</a> <br />
<a href="/wiki/Zimbabwe" title="Zimbabwe">Zimbabwe</a>
</p>
<ul>
<li><b>Observers:</b>
</li>
</ul>
<p><a href="/wiki/Andorra" title="Andorra">Andorra</a> (non-party to Kyoto) <br />
<a href="/wiki/Holy_See" title="Holy See">Holy See</a> (non-party to Kyoto) <br />
</p>
</td></tr></table>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Hidden_end&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Hidden end (page does not exist)">Template:Hidden end</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="U.S._position">U.S. position</span></h3>
<p>The U.S. signed the Protocol, but did not ratify it.  In the US, ratification of the Kyoto Protocol would require the treaty to be approved by both the Senate and Executive branch (i.e., the president) of the US government.  Before the Protocol was agreed on, the U.S. Senate passed the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Byrd-Hagel_Resolution&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Byrd-Hagel Resolution (page does not exist)">Byrd-Hagel Resolution</a> unanimously disapproving of any international agreement that 1) did not require developing countries to make emission reductions and 2) "would seriously harm the economy of the United States".<sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103">[103]</a></sup> Therefore, even though the <a href="/wiki/Clinton_administration" title="Clinton administration" class="mw-redirect">Clinton administration</a> signed the treaty,<sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104">[104]</a></sup> it remained only a symbolic act and was never submitted to the Senate for ratification.
</p><p>When <a href="/w/index.php?title=George_W._Bush&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="George W. Bush (page does not exist)">George W. Bush</a> was elected U.S. president in 2000, he was asked by <a href="/wiki/U.S._Senator" title="U.S. Senator" class="mw-redirect">U.S. Senator</a> <a href="/wiki/Chuck_Hagel" title="Chuck Hagel">Hagel</a> what his administration's position was on climate change. Bush replied that he took climate change "very seriously,"<sup id="cite_ref-105" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-105">[105]</a></sup> but that he opposed the Kyoto treaty, because "it exempts 80% of the world, including major population centers such as China and India, from compliance, and would cause serious harm to the US economy".<sup id="cite_ref-Dessai_2001_5_23-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dessai_2001_5-23">[23]</a></sup>  Almost all world leaders (e.g., China, Japan, South Africa, Pacific islands) expressed their disappointment over President Bush's decision not to support the treaty.<sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106">[106]</a></sup>
</p><p>The U.S. accounted for 36% of emissions in 1990, and without U.S. ratification, only an EU+Russia+Japan+small party coalition could place the treaty into legal effect. A deal was reached in the Bonn climate talks (COP-6.5), held in 2001.<sup id="cite_ref-107" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-107">[107]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Withdrawal_of_Canada">Withdrawal of Canada</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>In 2011, Canada, Japan and Russia stated that they would not take on further Kyoto targets.<sup id="cite_ref-canadaguardian_108-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-canadaguardian-108">[108]</a></sup> The Canadian government announced its withdrawal -possible at any time three years after ratification- from the Kyoto Protocol on 12 December 2011, effective 15 December 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109">[109]</a></sup> Canada was committed to cutting its greenhouse emissions to 6% below 1990 levels by 2012, but in 2009 emissions were 17% higher than in 1990. Environment minister <a href="/wiki/Peter_Kent" title="Peter Kent">Peter Kent</a> cited Canada's liability to "enormous financial penalties" under the treaty unless it withdrew.<sup id="cite_ref-canadaguardian_108-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-canadaguardian-108">[108]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110">[110]</a></sup>  He also suggested that the recently signed <a href="/w/index.php?title=2011_United_Nations_Climate_Change_Conference&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2011 United Nations Climate Change Conference (page does not exist)">Durban agreement</a> may provide an alternative way forward.<sup id="cite_ref-bbc_canada_withdrawal_111-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bbc_canada_withdrawal-111">[111]</a></sup> Canada's decision received a mixed response from representatives of other ratifying countries.<sup id="cite_ref-bbc_canada_withdrawal_111-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bbc_canada_withdrawal-111">[111]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Other_states_and_territories_where_the_treaty_is_not_applicable">Other states and territories where the treaty is not applicable</span></h3>
<p>Andorra, the United States and, following their withdrawal on 15 December 2012, Canada are the only UNFCCC Parties that are not party to the Protocol. Furthermore, the Protocol is not applied to UNFCCC observers <a href="/wiki/Palestine" title="Palestine">Palestine</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=South_Sudan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="South Sudan (page does not exist)">South Sudan</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Holy_See" title="Holy See">Holy See</a>. Although the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kingdom_of_the_Netherlands&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kingdom of the Netherlands (page does not exist)">Kingdom of the Netherlands</a> approved the protocol for the whole Kingdom, it did not deposit an instrument of ratification for Aruba, Curaçao, Sint Maarten or the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Caribbean_Netherlands&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Caribbean Netherlands (page does not exist)">Caribbean Netherlands</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112">[112]</a></sup> The United Kingdom did not extend its ratification to Anguilla, British Virgin Islands, Montserrat, Pitcairn Islands, Saint Helena, Ascension and Tristan da Cunha, Turks and Caicos Islands or the Sovereign Base Areas of Akrotiri and Dhekelia, while Denmark excluded application to the Faroe Islands<sup id="cite_ref-Ratification_of_Kyoto_5-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ratification_of_Kyoto-5">[5]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Government_action_and_emissions">Government action and emissions</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Annex_I_countries">Annex I countries</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:CO2emissions1.jpg" title="File:CO2emissions1.jpg">File:CO2emissions1.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Anthropogenic emissions of CO<sub>2</sub>-equivalents per year by the 10 largest emitters (the European Union is lumped as a single area, because of their integrated carbon trading scheme). Data sorted based on 2010 contributions. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Legend&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Legend (page does not exist)">Template:Legend</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Legend&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Legend (page does not exist)">Template:Legend</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Legend&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Legend (page does not exist)">Template:Legend</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Legend&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Legend (page does not exist)">Template:Legend</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Legend&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Legend (page does not exist)">Template:Legend</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Legend&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Legend (page does not exist)">Template:Legend</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Legend&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Legend (page does not exist)">Template:Legend</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Legend&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Legend (page does not exist)">Template:Legend</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Legend&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Legend (page does not exist)">Template:Legend</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Legend&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Legend (page does not exist)">Template:Legend</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Legend&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Legend (page does not exist)">Template:Legend</a></div></div></div>
<p>Total aggregate GHG emissions excluding emissions/removals from land use, land use change and forestry (LULUCF, i.e., carbon storage in forests and soils) for all Annex I Parties (see list below) including the United States taken together decreased from 19.0 to 17.8 thousand <a href="/wiki/Orders_of_magnitude_(mass)" title="Orders of magnitude (mass)">teragrams</a> (Tg, which is equal to 10<sup>9</sup>&#160;kg) <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Chem&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Chem (page does not exist)">Template:Chem</a> equivalent, a decline of 6.0% during the 1990-2008 period.<sup id="cite_ref-2011_unfccc_synthesis_of_annex_I_communications_113-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2011_unfccc_synthesis_of_annex_I_communications-113">[113]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a>  Several factors have contributed to this decline.<sup id="cite_ref-2011_unfccc_synthesis_of_annex_I_communications_113-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2011_unfccc_synthesis_of_annex_I_communications-113">[113]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a>  The first is due to the economic restructuring in the Annex I Economies in Transition<sup id="cite_ref-2011_unfccc_synthesis_of_annex_I_communications_113-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2011_unfccc_synthesis_of_annex_I_communications-113">[113]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a>  (the EITs – see <a href="/wiki/Kyoto_Protocol#Intergovernmental_Emissions_Trading" title="Kyoto Protocol">Intergovernmental Emissions Trading</a> for the list of EITs). Over the period 1990-1999, emissions fell by 40% in the EITs following the collapse of <a href="/wiki/Planned_economy" title="Planned economy">central planning</a> in the former <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a> and <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Europe" title="Eastern Europe">east European</a> countries.<sup id="cite_ref-Long_term_trend_in_global_CO2_emissions_114-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Long_term_trend_in_global_CO2_emissions-114">[114]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a>  This led to a massive contraction of their heavy industry-based economies, with associated reductions in their fossil fuel consumption and emissions.<sup id="cite_ref-2009_carbon_trust_carbon_market_57-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2009_carbon_trust_carbon_market-57">[57]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a>
</p><p>Emissions growth in Annex I Parties have also been limited due to policies and measures (PaMs).<sup id="cite_ref-2011_unfccc_synthesis_of_annex_I_communications_113-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2011_unfccc_synthesis_of_annex_I_communications-113">[113]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a> In particular, PaMs were strengthened after 2000, helping to enhance energy efficiency and develop renewable energy sources.<sup id="cite_ref-2011_unfccc_synthesis_of_annex_I_communications_113-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2011_unfccc_synthesis_of_annex_I_communications-113">[113]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a> Energy use also decreased during the economic crisis in 2007-2008.<sup id="cite_ref-2011_unfccc_synthesis_of_annex_I_communications_113-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2011_unfccc_synthesis_of_annex_I_communications-113">[113]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Projections">Projections</span></h4>
<p>UNFCCC (2011)<sup id="cite_ref-2011_unfccc_synthesis_of_annex_I_communications_113-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2011_unfccc_synthesis_of_annex_I_communications-113">[113]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a> made projections of changes in emissions of the Annex I Parties and the effectiveness of their PaMs. It was noted that their projections should be interpreted with caution.<sup id="cite_ref-2011_unfccc_synthesis_of_annex_I_communications_113-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2011_unfccc_synthesis_of_annex_I_communications-113">[113]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a>  For the 39 Annex I Parties, UNFCCC (2011) projected that existing PaMs would lead to annual emissions in 2010 of 17.5 thousand Tg <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Chem&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Chem (page does not exist)">Template:Chem</a> eq, excluding LULUCF, which is a decrease of 6.7% from the 1990 level.<sup id="cite_ref-2011_unfccc_synthesis_of_annex_I_communications_113-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2011_unfccc_synthesis_of_annex_I_communications-113">[113]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a> Annual emissions in 2020 excluding LULUCF were projected to reach 18.9 thousand Tg <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Chem&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Chem (page does not exist)">Template:Chem</a> eq, which is an increase of 0.6% on the 1990 level.<sup id="cite_ref-2011_unfccc_synthesis_of_annex_I_communications_113-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2011_unfccc_synthesis_of_annex_I_communications-113">[113]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a>
</p><p>UNFCCC (2011)<sup id="cite_ref-2011_unfccc_synthesis_of_annex_I_communications_113-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2011_unfccc_synthesis_of_annex_I_communications-113">[113]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a> made an estimate of the total effect of implemented and adopted PaMs. Projected savings were estimated relative to a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Economics_of_climate_change_mitigation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Economics of climate change mitigation (page does not exist)">reference (baseline) scenario</a> where PaMs are not implemented.  PaMs were projected to deliver emissions savings relative to baseline of about 1.5 thousand Tg <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Chem&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Chem (page does not exist)">Template:Chem</a> eq by 2010, and 2.8 thousand Tg <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Chem&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Chem (page does not exist)">Template:Chem</a> eq by 2020.<sup id="cite_ref-2011_unfccc_synthesis_of_annex_I_communications_113-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2011_unfccc_synthesis_of_annex_I_communications-113">[113]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a>  In percentage terms, and using annual emissions in the year 1990 as a reference point, PaMs were projected to deliver at least a 5.0% reduction relative to baseline by 2010, and a 10.0% reduction relative to baseline in 2020.<sup id="cite_ref-2011_unfccc_synthesis_of_annex_I_communications_113-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2011_unfccc_synthesis_of_annex_I_communications-113">[113]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a> Scenarios reviewed by UNFCCC (2011)<sup id="cite_ref-2011_unfccc_synthesis_of_annex_I_communications_113-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2011_unfccc_synthesis_of_annex_I_communications-113">[113]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a> still suggested that total Annex I annual emissions would increase out to 2020 (see the preceding paragraph).
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Annex_I_Parties_with_targets">Annex I Parties with targets</span></h4>
<table class="wikitable">

<td> +2.7
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> New Zealand </td>
<td> 0 </td>
<td> - </td>
<td> +62.4 </td>
<td> +22.7 </td>
<td> +34.3
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <i>Economies in<br />Transition</i> </td>
<td> - </td>
<td> - </td>
<td> - </td>
<td> -36.2
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> Bulgaria </td>
<td> -8 </td>
<td> -20<sup id="cite_ref-EU_122-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EU-122">[122]</a></sup> </td>
<td>  -45.5 </td>
<td> -42.8 </td>
<td> -43.7
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> Croatia </td>
<td> -5 </td>
<td> -20<sup id="cite_ref-EU_122-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EU-122">[122]</a></sup> </td>
<td> -13.7 </td>
<td> -0.9 </td>
<td> -8.4
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> Czech Republic </td>
<td> -8 </td>
<td> -20<sup id="cite_ref-EU_122-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EU-122">[122]</a></sup> </td>
<td> -28.7 </td>
<td> -27.5 </td>
<td> -29.2
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> Estonia </td>
<td> -8 </td>
<td>-20<sup id="cite_ref-EU_122-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EU-122">[122]</a></sup> </td>
<td>  -69.9 </td>
<td> -50.9 </td>
<td> -59.4
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> Hungary </td>
<td> -8 </td>
<td> -20<sup id="cite_ref-EU_122-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EU-122">[122]</a></sup> </td>
<td> -38.1 </td>
<td> -36.2 </td>
<td> -27.8
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> Latvia </td>
<td> -8 </td>
<td> -20<sup id="cite_ref-EU_122-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EU-122">[122]</a></sup> </td>
<td> -307.9 </td>
<td> -55.6 </td>
<td> -63.8
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> Lithuania </td>
<td> -8 </td>
<td> -20<sup id="cite_ref-EU_122-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EU-122">[122]</a></sup> </td>
<td> -69.1 </td>
<td> -51.8 </td>
<td> -62.6
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> Poland </td>
<td> -6 </td>
<td> -20<sup id="cite_ref-EU_122-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EU-122">[122]</a></sup> </td>
<td>  -34.4 </td>
<td> -29.6 </td>
<td> -16.2
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> Romania </td>
<td> -8 </td>
<td> -20<sup id="cite_ref-EU_122-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EU-122">[122]</a></sup> </td>
<td>  -53.5 </td>
<td> -45.9 </td>
<td> -53.1
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> Russian<br />Federation </td>
<td> 0 </td>
<td> - </td>
<td> -52.8 </td>
<td> -32.8 </td>
<td> -29.7
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> Slovak<br />Republic </td>
<td> -8 </td>
<td> -20<sup id="cite_ref-EU_122-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EU-122">[122]</a></sup> </td>
<td> -34.4 </td>
<td> -33.7 </td>
<td> -41.5
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> Slovenia </td>
<td> -8 </td>
<td> -20<sup id="cite_ref-EU_122-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EU-122">[122]</a></sup> </td>
<td> +5.2 </td>
<td> +5.2 </td>
<td> +21.2
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> Ukraine </td>
<td> 0 </td>
<td>  -24 </td>
<td> -52.2 </td>
<td> -53.9 </td>
<td> -62.7
</td></tr></table>
<p><i>Data given in the table above may not be fully reflective of a country's progress towards meeting its first-round Kyoto target. The summary below contains more up-to-date information on how close countries are to meeting their first-round targets.</i>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Carbon_dioxide_emissions_from_fuel_combustion_of_Annex_I_Kyoto_Protocol_Parties_1990-2009.png" title="File:Carbon dioxide emissions from fuel combustion of Annex I Kyoto Protocol Parties 1990-2009.png">File:Carbon dioxide emissions from fuel combustion of Annex I Kyoto Protocol Parties 1990-2009.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:CO2&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:CO2 (page does not exist)">Template:CO2</a> emissions from fuel combustion of Annex I Kyoto Protocol (KP) Parties, 1990-2009. Total Annex I KP emissions are shown, along with emissions of Annex II KP and Annex I EITs.</div></div></div>
<p>Collectively the group of industrialized countries committed to a Kyoto target, i.e., the Annex I countries excluding the USA, have a target of reducing their GHG emissions by 4.2% on average for the period 2008-2012 relative to the base year, which in most cases is 1990.<sup id="cite_ref-Long_term_trend_in_global_CO2_emissions_114-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Long_term_trend_in_global_CO2_emissions-114">[114]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a>  According to Olivier <i>et al.</i> (2011),<sup id="cite_ref-Long_term_trend_in_global_CO2_emissions_114-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Long_term_trend_in_global_CO2_emissions-114">[114]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a> the Kyoto Parties will comfortably exceed their collective target, with a projected average reduction of 16% for 2008-2012. This projection excludes both LULUCF and credits generated by the Clean Development Mechanism (CDM).<sup id="cite_ref-Long_term_trend_in_global_CO2_emissions_114-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Long_term_trend_in_global_CO2_emissions-114">[114]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a>
</p><p>As noted in the preceding section, between 1990–1999, there was a large reduction in the emissions of the EITs.<sup id="cite_ref-Long_term_trend_in_global_CO2_emissions_114-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Long_term_trend_in_global_CO2_emissions-114">[114]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a> The reduction in the EITs is largely responsible for the total (aggregate) reduction (excluding LULUCF) in emissions of the Annex I countries, excluding the USA.<sup id="cite_ref-Long_term_trend_in_global_CO2_emissions_114-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Long_term_trend_in_global_CO2_emissions-114">[114]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a> Emissions of the Annex II countries (Annex I minus the EIT countries) have experienced a limited increase in emissions from 1990–2006, followed by stabilization and a more marked decrease from 2007 onwards.<sup id="cite_ref-Long_term_trend_in_global_CO2_emissions_114-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Long_term_trend_in_global_CO2_emissions-114">[114]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a> The emissions reductions in the early nineties by the 12 EIT countries who have since joined the EU, assist the present EU-27 in meeting its collective Kyoto target.<sup id="cite_ref-Long_term_trend_in_global_CO2_emissions_114-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Long_term_trend_in_global_CO2_emissions-114">[114]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a>
</p><p>Almost all European countries are on track to achieve their first-round Kyoto targets.<sup id="cite_ref-eea_1st_round_kyoto_124-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-eea_1st_round_kyoto-124">[124]</a></sup> Spain plans to meet its target by purchasing a large quantity of Kyoto units through the flexibility mechanisms.<sup id="cite_ref-eea_1st_round_kyoto_124-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-eea_1st_round_kyoto-124">[124]</a></sup> Australia,<sup id="cite_ref-Long_term_trend_in_global_CO2_emissions_114-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Long_term_trend_in_global_CO2_emissions-114">[114]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a> Canada<sup id="cite_ref-Long_term_trend_in_global_CO2_emissions_114-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Long_term_trend_in_global_CO2_emissions-114">[114]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a> (Canada withdrew from the Kyoto treaty in 2012),<sup id="cite_ref-vaughan_2011_canada_withdrawal_125-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-vaughan_2011_canada_withdrawal-125">[125]</a></sup> and Italy<sup id="cite_ref-eea_1st_round_kyoto_124-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-eea_1st_round_kyoto-124">[124]</a></sup> are not on course to meet their first-round Kyoto targets. In order to meet their targets, these countries would need to purchase emissions credits from other Kyoto countries.<sup id="cite_ref-Long_term_trend_in_global_CO2_emissions_114-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Long_term_trend_in_global_CO2_emissions-114">[114]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a> As noted in the section on <a href="/wiki/Kyoto_Protocol#Intergovernmental_Emissions_Trading" title="Kyoto Protocol">Intergovernmental Emissions Trading</a>, purchasing surplus credits from the EIT countries would not actually result in total emissions being reduced. An alternative would be the purchase of CDM credits or the use of the voluntary Green Investment Scheme.
</p><p>In December 2011, Canada's environment minister, <a href="/wiki/Peter_Kent" title="Peter Kent">Peter Kent</a>, formally announced that <a href="/w/index.php?title=Climate_change_in_Canada&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Climate change in Canada (page does not exist)">Canada</a> would withdraw from the Kyoto accord a day after the end of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2011_United_Nations_Climate_Change_Conference&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2011 United Nations Climate Change Conference (page does not exist)">2011 United Nations Climate Change Conference</a> (see the section on the <a href="/wiki/Kyoto_Protocol#Withdrawal_of_Canada" title="Kyoto Protocol">withdrawal of Canada</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-vaughan_2011_canada_withdrawal_125-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-vaughan_2011_canada_withdrawal-125">[125]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Annex_I_Parties_without_Kyoto_targets">Annex I Parties without Kyoto targets</span></h4>
<p>Belarus, Malta, and Turkey are Annex I Parties but do not have first-round Kyoto targets.<sup id="cite_ref-126" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-126">[126]</a></sup> The US has a Kyoto target of a 6% reduction relative to the 1990 level, but has not ratified the treaty.<sup id="cite_ref-Long_term_trend_in_global_CO2_emissions_114-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Long_term_trend_in_global_CO2_emissions-114">[114]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a>  Emissions in the US have increased 11% since 1990, and according to Olivier <i>et al.</i> (2011),<sup id="cite_ref-Long_term_trend_in_global_CO2_emissions_114-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Long_term_trend_in_global_CO2_emissions-114">[114]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a>  it will be unable to meet its original Kyoto target.
</p><p>If the US had ratified the Kyoto Protocol, the average percentage reduction in total GHG emissions for the Annex I group would have been a 5.2% reduction relative to the base year.<sup id="cite_ref-Long_term_trend_in_global_CO2_emissions_114-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Long_term_trend_in_global_CO2_emissions-114">[114]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a> Including the US in their calculation, Olivier <i>et al.</i> (2011)<sup id="cite_ref-Long_term_trend_in_global_CO2_emissions_114-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Long_term_trend_in_global_CO2_emissions-114">[114]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a>  projected that the Annex I countries would collectively achieve a 7% reduction relative to the base year, which is lower than the original target of a 5.2% reduction. This projection excludes expected purchases of emissions credits.<sup id="cite_ref-Long_term_trend_in_global_CO2_emissions_114-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Long_term_trend_in_global_CO2_emissions-114">[114]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Non-Annex_I">Non-Annex I</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Multiple_image&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Multiple image (page does not exist)">Template:Multiple image</a>
</p><p>UNFCCC (2005) compiled and synthesized information reported to it by non-Annex I Parties.<sup id="cite_ref-2005_unfccc_non-annex_i_summary_47-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2005_unfccc_non-annex_i_summary-47">[47]</a></sup> Most non-Annex I Parties belonged in the low-income group, with very few classified as middle-income.<sup id="cite_ref-2005_unfccc_non-annex_i_summary_47-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2005_unfccc_non-annex_i_summary-47">[47]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a> Most Parties included information on policies relating to <a href="/wiki/Sustainable_development" title="Sustainable development">sustainable development</a>. Sustainable development priorities mentioned by non-Annex I Parties included poverty alleviation and access to basic education and health care.<sup id="cite_ref-2005_unfccc_non-annex_i_summary_47-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2005_unfccc_non-annex_i_summary-47">[47]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a> Many non-Annex I Parties are making efforts to amend and update their <a href="/w/index.php?title=Environmental_legislation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Environmental legislation (page does not exist)">environmental legislation</a> to include global concerns such as climate change.<sup id="cite_ref-2005_unfccc_non-annex_i_summary_47-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2005_unfccc_non-annex_i_summary-47">[47]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a>
</p><p>A few Parties, e.g., South Africa and <a href="/wiki/Iran" title="Iran">Iran</a>, stated their concern over how efforts to reduce emissions by Annex I Parties could adversely affect their economies.<sup id="cite_ref-2005_unfccc_non-annex_i_summary_47-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2005_unfccc_non-annex_i_summary-47">[47]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a> The economies of these countries are highly dependent on income generated from the production, processing, and export of <a href="/wiki/Fossil_fuel" title="Fossil fuel">fossil fuels</a>.
</p><p><b>Emissions</b>
</p><p>GHG emissions, excluding land use change and forestry (LUCF), reported by 122 non-Annex I Parties for the year 1994 or the closest year reported, totalled 11.7&#160;billion tonnes (billion&#160;=&#160;1,000,000,000) of CO<sub>2</sub>-eq. CO<sub>2</sub> was the largest proportion of emissions (63%), followed by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Methane&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Methane (page does not exist)">methane</a> (26%) and <a href="/wiki/Nitrous_oxide" title="Nitrous oxide">nitrous oxide</a> (N<sub>2</sub>O) (11%).
</p><p>The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Energy_sector&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Energy sector (page does not exist)">energy sector</a> was the largest source of emissions for 70 Parties, whereas for 45 Parties the agriculture sector was the largest. Per capita emissions (in tonnes of CO<sub>2</sub>-eq, excluding LUCF) averaged 2.8&#160;tonnes for the 122 non-Annex I Parties.
</p>
<ul>
<li>The Africa region's <a href="/w/index.php?title=Aggregate_data&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Aggregate data (page does not exist)">aggregate</a> emissions were 1.6&#160;billion&#160;tonnes, with per capita emissions of 2.4&#160;tonnes.
</li>
<li>The Asia and Pacific region's aggregate emissions were 7.9&#160;billion&#160;tonnes, with per capita emissions of 2.6&#160;tonnes.
</li>
<li>The Latin America and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Caribbean&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Caribbean (page does not exist)">Caribbean</a> region's aggregate emissions were 2&#160;billion&#160;tonnes, with per capita emissions of 4.6&#160;tonnes.
</li>
<li>The "other" region includes <a href="/wiki/Albania" title="Albania">Albania</a>, Armenia, <a href="/wiki/Azerbaijan" title="Azerbaijan">Azerbaijan</a>, Georgia, Malta, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Republic_of_Moldova&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Republic of Moldova (page does not exist)">Moldova</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Republic_of_Macedonia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Republic of Macedonia (page does not exist)">Macedonia</a>. Their aggregate emissions were 0.1&#160;billion&#160;tonnes, with per capita emissions of 5.1&#160;tonnes.
</li>
</ul>
<p>Parties reported a high level of uncertainty in LUCF emissions, but in aggregate, there appeared to only be a small difference of 1.7% with and without LUCF. With LUCF, emissions were 11.9&#160;billion&#160;tonnes, without LUCF, total aggregate emissions were 11.7&#160;billion&#160;tonnes.
</p><p><i>Trends</i>
</p><p>In several large developing countries and fast growing economies (China, India, Thailand, Indonesia, Egypt, and Iran) GHG emissions have increased rapidly (PBL, 2009).<sup id="cite_ref-127" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-127">[127]</a></sup>  For example, emissions in China have risen strongly over the 1990–2005 period, often by more than 10% year. Emissions per-capita in non-Annex I countries are still, for the most part, much lower than in industrialized countries. Non-Annex I countries do not have quantitative emission reduction commitments, but they are committed to mitigation actions. China, for example, has had a national policy programme to reduce emissions growth, which included the closure of old, less efficient coal-fired power plants.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Cost_estimates">Cost estimates</span></h2>
<p>Barker <i>et al.</i> (2007, p.&#160;79) assessed the literature on cost estimates for the Kyoto Protocol.<sup id="cite_ref-128" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-128">[128]</a></sup> Due to non-US participation in the Kyoto treaty, costs estimates were found to be much lower than those estimated in the previous <a href="/wiki/IPCC_Third_Assessment_Report" title="IPCC Third Assessment Report">IPCC Third Assessment Report</a>. Without US participation, and with full use of the Kyoto flexible mechanisms, costs were estimated at less than 0.05% of Annex B GDP. This compared to earlier estimates of 0.1–1.1%. Without use of the flexible mechanisms, costs without US participation were estimated at less than 0.1%. This compared to earlier estimates of 0.2–2%. These cost estimates were viewed as being based on much evidence and high agreement in the literature.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Views_on_the_Protocol">Views on the Protocol</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>Gupta <i>et al.</i> (2007) assessed the literature on climate change policy. They found that no authoritative assessments of the UNFCCC or its Protocol asserted that these agreements had, or will, succeed in solving the climate problem.<sup id="cite_ref-gupta_36-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gupta-36">[36]</a></sup> In these assessments, it was assumed that the UNFCCC or its Protocol would not be changed. The Framework Convention and its Protocol include provisions for future policy actions to be taken.
</p><p>Gupta <i>et al.</i> (2007)<sup id="cite_ref-gupta_kyoto_assessment_129-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gupta_kyoto_assessment-129">[129]</a></sup>  described the Kyoto first-round commitments as "modest," stating that they acted as a constraint on the treaty's effectiveness. It was suggested that subsequent Kyoto commitments could be made more effective with measures aimed at achieving deeper cuts in emissions, as well as having policies applied to a larger share of global emissions.<sup id="cite_ref-gupta_kyoto_assessment_129-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gupta_kyoto_assessment-129">[129]</a></sup> In 2008, countries with a Kyoto cap made up less than one-third of annual global carbon dioxide emissions from fuel <a href="/wiki/Combustion" title="Combustion">combustion</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-130" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-130">[130]</a></sup>
</p><p>World Bank (2010)<sup id="cite_ref-world_bank_kyoto_comments_131-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-world_bank_kyoto_comments-131">[131]</a></sup> commented on how the Kyoto Protocol had only had a slight effect on curbing global emissions growth. The treaty was negotiated in 1997, but in 2006, energy-related carbon dioxide emissions had grown by 24%.<sup id="cite_ref-132" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-132">[132]</a></sup> World Bank (2010) also stated that the treaty had provided only limited financial support to developing countries to assist them in reducing their emissions and adapting to climate change.<sup id="cite_ref-world_bank_kyoto_comments_131-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-world_bank_kyoto_comments-131">[131]</a></sup>
</p><p>Some of the criticism of the Protocol has been based on the idea of climate justice (Liverman, 2008, p.&#160;14).<sup id="cite_ref-liverman_43-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-liverman-43">[43]</a></sup>
This has particularly centred on the balance between the low emissions and high vulnerability of the developing world to climate change, compared to high emissions in the developed world.
</p><p>Some environmentalists have supported the Kyoto Protocol because it is "the only game in town," and possibly because they expect that future emission reduction commitments may demand more stringent emission reductions (Aldy <i>et al.</i>., 2003, p.&#160;9).<sup id="cite_ref-aldy_133-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-aldy-133">[133]</a></sup> In 2001, seventeen national science academies stated that ratification of the Protocol represented a "small but essential first step towards stabilising atmospheric concentrations of greenhouse gases."<sup id="cite_ref-134" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-134">[134]</a></sup> Some environmentalists and scientists have criticized the existing commitments for being too weak (Grubb, 2000, p.&#160;5).<sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-135">[135]</a></sup>
</p><p>The United States (under former President <a href="/w/index.php?title=George_W._Bush&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="George W. Bush (page does not exist)">George W. Bush</a>) and Australia (initially, under former Prime Minister <a href="/w/index.php?title=John_Howard&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="John Howard (page does not exist)">John Howard</a>) did not ratify the Kyoto treaty.<sup id="cite_ref-stern_us_and_australia_136-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-stern_us_and_australia-136">[136]</a></sup> According to Stern (2006),<sup id="cite_ref-stern_us_and_australia_136-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-stern_us_and_australia-136">[136]</a></sup> their decision was based on the lack of quantitative emission commitments for emerging economies (see also the <a href="/wiki/Kyoto_Protocol#2000_onwards" title="Kyoto Protocol">2000 onwards</a> section). Australia, under former Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Kevin_Rudd" title="Kevin Rudd">Kevin Rudd</a>, has since ratified the treaty,<sup id="cite_ref-137" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-137">[137]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-australia_signing_138-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-australia_signing-138">[138]</a></sup> which took effect in March 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-139" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-139">[139]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Views_on_the_flexibility_mechanisms">Views on the flexibility mechanisms</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>Another area which has been commented on is the role of the Kyoto <a href="/w/index.php?title=Flexibility_mechanisms&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Flexibility mechanisms (page does not exist)">flexibility mechanisms</a> – <a href="/wiki/Emissions_trading" title="Emissions trading">emissions trading</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Joint_Implementation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Joint Implementation (page does not exist)">Joint Implementation</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Clean_Development_Mechanism" title="Clean Development Mechanism">Clean Development Mechanism</a> (CDM).<sup id="cite_ref-toth_flexibility_mechanisms_140-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-toth_flexibility_mechanisms-140">[140]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-141" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-141">[141]</a></sup> The flexibility mechanisms have attracted both positive and negative comments.<sup id="cite_ref-142" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-142">[142]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-143" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-143">[143]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-144" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-144">[144]</a></sup>
</p><p>As mentioned earlier, a number of Annex I Parties have implemented emissions trading schemes (ETSs) as part of efforts to meet their Kyoto commitments. General commentaries on emissions trading are contained in <a href="/wiki/Emissions_trading" title="Emissions trading">emissions trading</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Carbon_emission_trading&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Carbon emission trading (page does not exist)">carbon emission trading</a>. Individual articles on the ETSs contain commentaries on these schemes (see <a href="/wiki/Kyoto_Protocol#International_Emissions_Trading" title="Kyoto Protocol">Kyoto Protocol#International Emissions Trading</a> for a list of ETSs).
</p><p>One of the arguments made in favour of the flexibility mechanisms is that they can reduce the costs incurred by Annex I Parties in meeting their Kyoto commitments.<sup id="cite_ref-toth_flexibility_mechanisms_140-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-toth_flexibility_mechanisms-140">[140]</a></sup> Criticisms of flexibility have, for example, included the ineffectiveness of emissions trading in promoting investment in non-fossil energy sources,<sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145">[145]</a></sup> and adverse impacts of CDM projects on local communities in developing countries.<sup id="cite_ref-146" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-146">[146]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Conference_of_the_Parties">Conference of the Parties</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
The official meeting of all states party to the Kyoto Protocol is the <i>Conference of the Parties</i>. It is held every year as part of the United Nations Climate Change conference, which also serves as the formal meeting of UNFCCC. The first <a href="/w/index.php?title=Meetings_of_Parties_of_the_Kyoto_Protocol_(MOP)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Meetings of Parties of the Kyoto Protocol (MOP) (page does not exist)">Meetings of Parties of the Kyoto Protocol (MOP)</a> was held in 2005 in conjunction with the eleventh Conferences of parties to UNFCCC. Also <a href="/w/index.php?title=Parties_to_the_Convention_that_are_not_parties_to_the_Protocol&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Parties to the Convention that are not parties to the Protocol (page does not exist)">parties to the Convention that are not parties to the Protocol</a> can participate in Protocol-related meetings as observers. The first conference was held in 1995 in Berlin, while the 2013 conference was held in <a href="/w/index.php?title=2013_United_Nations_Climate_Change_Conference&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2013 United Nations Climate Change Conference (page does not exist)">Warsaw</a>.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Amendment_and_possible_successors">Amendment and possible successors</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>In the non-binding '<a href="/w/index.php?title=G8%2B5&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="G8+5 (page does not exist)">Washington Declaration'</a> agreed on 16 February 2007, heads of governments from Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, Russia, the United Kingdom, the United States, Brazil, <a href="/w/index.php?title=People%27s_Republic_of_China&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="People's Republic of China (page does not exist)">China</a>, <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mexico&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mexico (page does not exist)">Mexico</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=South_Africa&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="South Africa (page does not exist)">South Africa</a> agreed in principle on the outline of a successor to the Kyoto Protocol. They envisaged a global cap-and-trade system that would apply to both industrialized nations and <a href="/wiki/Developing_country" title="Developing country">developing countries</a>, and initially hoped that it would be in place by 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-147" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-147">[147]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-148" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-148">[148]</a></sup>
</p><p>The United Nations Climate Change Conference in Copenhagen in December 2009 was one of the annual series of UN meetings that followed the 1992 Earth Summit in Rio. In 1997 the talks led to the Kyoto Protocol, and the conference in Copenhagen was considered to be the opportunity to agree a successor to Kyoto that would bring about meaningful carbon cuts.<sup id="cite_ref-149" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-149">[149]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-150" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-150">[150]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_United_Nations_Climate_Change_Conference&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2010 United Nations Climate Change Conference (page does not exist)">2010 Cancún agreements</a> include voluntary pledges made by 76 developed and developing countries to control their emissions of greenhouse gases.<sup id="cite_ref-king_2011_cancun_agreement_151-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-king_2011_cancun_agreement-151">[151]</a></sup> In 2010, these 76 countries were collectively responsible for 85% of annual global emissions.<sup id="cite_ref-king_2011_cancun_agreement_151-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-king_2011_cancun_agreement-151">[151]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-unep_2012_emissions_gap_152-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-unep_2012_emissions_gap-152">[152]</a></sup>
</p><p>By May 2012, the USA, Japan, Russia, and Canada had indicated they would not sign up to a second Kyoto commitment period.<sup id="cite_ref-153" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-153">[153]</a></sup> In November 2012, Australia confirmed it would participate in a second commitment period under the Kyoto Protocol and New Zealand confirmed that it would not.<sup id="cite_ref-154" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-154">[154]</a></sup>
</p><p>New Zealand's climate minister Tim Groser said the 15-year-old Kyoto Protocol was outdated, and that New Zealand was "ahead of the curve" in looking for a replacement that would include developing nations.<sup id="cite_ref-155" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-155">[155]</a></sup> Non-profit environmental organisations such as the <a href="/wiki/World_Wildlife_Fund" title="World Wildlife Fund" class="mw-redirect">World Wildlife Fund</a> criticised New Zealand's decision to pull out.<sup id="cite_ref-156" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-156">[156]</a></sup>
</p><p>On 8 December 2012, at the end of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2012_United_Nations_Climate_Change_Conference&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2012 United Nations Climate Change Conference (page does not exist)">2012 United Nations Climate Change Conference</a>, an agreement was reached to extend the Protocol to 2020 and to set a date of 2015 for the development of a successor document, to be implemented from 2020 (see lede for more information).<sup id="cite_ref-157" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-157">[157]</a></sup> The outcome of the Doha talks has received a mixed response,<sup id="cite_ref-ritter_2012_doha_talks_8-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ritter_2012_doha_talks-8">[8]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-harrabin_2012_doha_talks_9-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-harrabin_2012_doha_talks-9">[9]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-harvey_2012_doha_talks_10-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-harvey_2012_doha_talks-10">[10]</a></sup> with small island states critical of the overall package.<sup id="cite_ref-harrabin_2012_doha_talks_9-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-harrabin_2012_doha_talks-9">[9]</a></sup> The Kyoto second commitment period applies to about 15% of annual global emissions of greenhouse gases.<sup id="cite_ref-ritter_2012_doha_talks_8-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ritter_2012_doha_talks-8">[8]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-harrabin_2012_doha_talks_9-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-harrabin_2012_doha_talks-9">[9]</a></sup> Other results of the conference include a timetable for a global agreement to be adopted by 2015 which includes all countries.<sup id="cite_ref-unfccc_2012_doha_press_release_158-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-unfccc_2012_doha_press_release-158">[158]</a></sup>
</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Further_reading">Further reading</span></h2>
<ul>
<li> Ekardt, F./von Hövel, A.: <i>Distributive Justice, Competitiveness, and Transnational Climate Protection</i>. In: Carbon &amp; Climate Law Review, Vol. 3., 2009, p.&#160;102–114.
</li>
<li> Katy Longden, Roshni Pabari, Munir Hassan, and Dalia Majumder-Russel, "<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://a4id.org/sites/default/files/files/%5BA4ID%5D%20Climate%20change%20Mitigation%20and%20Adaptation.pdf">Climate Change: Mitigation and Adaptation (A Legal Guide)</a>."  Advocates for International Development (June 2012) 
</li>
</ul>
<p><br />
</p>

</dl>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="External_links">External links</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sister&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sister (page does not exist)">Template:Sister</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sister&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sister (page does not exist)">Template:Sister</a>
</p>
<ul>
<li> Protocol text (<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://unfccc.int/resource/docs/convkp/kpeng.html">HTML</a> and <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://unfccc.int/resource/docs/convkp/kpeng.pdf">PDF</a>), <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://treaties.un.org/doc/Publication/CTC/Ch_XXVII-7-b.pdf">2007</a> and <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://treaties.un.org/doc/Publication/CTC/Ch_XXVII-7-c.pdf">2012 amendment</a>
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://treaties.un.org/pages/ViewDetails.aspx?src=TREATY&amp;mtdsg_no=XXVII-7-a&amp;chapter=27&amp;lang=en">List of countries who have ratified, accepted, approved, or accessed the Kyoto Protocol</a>, its <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://treaties.un.org/pages/ViewDetails.aspx?src=TREATY&amp;mtdsg_no=XXVII-7-b&amp;chapter=27&amp;lang=en">first amendment</a> (Targets for Belarus) and its <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://treaties.un.org/pages/ViewDetails.aspx?src=TREATY&amp;mtdsg_no=XXVII-7-c&amp;chapter=27&amp;lang=en">second amendment</a> (extension period 2012-2020)
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://zvon.org/law/r/kyoto.html">Kyoto Protocol to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change at Law-Ref.org</a> – fully indexed and crosslinked with other documents
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://mindprod.com/environment/kyoto.html">The layman's guide to the Kyoto Protocol</a>
</li>
<li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://spreadsheets.google.com/ccc?key=0AmCeWwNKr6FmdGZLWGotWGNfcUtYWmkyalJIb21vbnc&amp;hl=en%3Cbr%20%3E%3C/a%3E#gid=0">Kyoto: On Target? – Google Docs</a>
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://legal.un.org/avl/ha/kpccc/kpccc.html">Introductory note by Laurence Boisson de Chazournes, procedural history note and audiovisual material</a> on the <i>Kyoto Protocol to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change</i> in the <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://legal.un.org/avl/historicarchives.html">Historic Archives of the United Nations Audiovisual Library of International Law</a>
</li>
</ul>

(page does not exist)">Treaties extended to the Faroe Islands</a></li><li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Category:Treaties_extended_to_Hong_Kong&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Category:Treaties extended to Hong Kong (page does not exist)">Treaties extended to Hong Kong</a></li><li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Category:Treaties_extended_to_Macau&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Category:Treaties extended to Macau (page does not exist)">Treaties extended to Macau</a></li></ul></div></div>												<div class="visualClear"></div>
							</div>
		</div>
